question: Explain the difference in the ease of bromination between cyclohexene and benzene

keypoints.answer: Addition of bromine to benzene is harder than addition of bromine to cyclohexene.
Cyclohexene readily reacts with bromine water.
Large localised electron density of the C=C double bond in alkenes can create dipoles on the bromine molecule.
Benzene's delocalised electrons are spread over all 6 carbons in the ring.
Benzene has a lower pi-electron density than alkenes.
Benzene is very stable due to the delocalisation of benzene ring.
Delocalisation makes it harder to produce dipoles on the halogen molecule (hence the need for halogen carrier).
High electron density of double bond in cyclohexene makes it easier to form dipoles on the halogen molecule.
